sp.p: And then terrified me, that the wind of her humour should be still against me, to cross me in every thing I desired, yet the course of my destiny should be more impetuous than before.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: The old gentleman did but dream so.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Nay more, she said I was an old dry stump, that had not the least drop of moisture in me, yet by the virtue of her humidity, she would make my temples so supple, that they should sprout, and bud a fresh.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Come she would not say so.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Yes, and that all my estate should be too little, to maintain her in prodigality, and invite acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman, I told him how other women used their husbands, but I would conform myself to obedience.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ay, that you might know what a blessing you had in her.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O was it so? I cry you mercy, I mistook you. Here take this pearl for amends; I am sorry I have sinned against so sweet a simplicity.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Come I knew you were in an error.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Then to avoid all cavillation hereafter, see what I have provided.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I have here a Syngraphus, a writing with articles, that must be drawn between us, before there can be any copulation.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Wherefore, did you so?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Look you sir, I was in a little suspense of her behaviour, and therefore in relation of that, which I thought she objected, yet has since proved to be otherwise: notwithstanding these rules, which may so much conduce to my happiness, and have been so much advised upon with deliberation, I would have established.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Pray let's hear them.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: They are only some sew propositions, and exceptions to be observed on her behalf, for the better security of my quiet, when I shall be married to her.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Now I conceive you, read them out.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: First, that after Hymen has once joined us together, she shall admit of no man whatsoever, to entitle him with any suspicious name of friend, or servant: do you mark me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well proceed.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Next ▪ if any of her old acquaintance come to visit her, as nurses, midwives, and the like, creatures of secrecy, she shall return them word, she is not within, or otherwise accommodated.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I'll have it written so upon the doors.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You may perceive by her silence, she will consent to any thing.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Then to avoid all occasions of writing epistles, she shall receive none, nor have any paper, pen, ink, or wax in her closet.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That's somewhat hard.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She shall not have any masculine bawdy picture hang in her chamber, but shall take it down, and sell it away as a thing unprofitable, and an enticement of fantasy.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That in my conceit is very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She shall bid no man to dinner, but I will invite them, and when they are set, she shall not cast amorous glances upon them, nor drink to them, nor lick her lips at them, nor show her teeth when she laughs, nor her tongue when she sneezes.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: For all these, I'll engage myself.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Besides, she shall not take upon her, to contrary me in any thing, nor seem more or less wise than myself.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That's not much amiss neither.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She shall send no hieroglyphics, nor meat cut in characters, nor tread upon any man's foot under the table, nor when they are risen, give them her hand to kiss, or open her palm to have her fortune told her, nor yet show them her ring, or receive any of theirs, and read the poesies.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She shall know no language but her own, nor speak any equivocating word.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: In my mind now these laws are very consonant to a good disposition, and if I were to marry myself, I'd propose the like.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: And for her religion, she may pray to any innocent goddess, as Diana and the graces, but if she have any thing to say to Mars, Mercury, or Apollo, she shall acquaint me with it, and I will present her devotions.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Have you done now?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Last of all, when she is ready to go to bed, she shall not put out the candle to walk up and down in her smock, and shake her body in the dark, and if she be content, I take her as my own.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: All these she shall subscribe to, if she be my daughter.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Why then we'll proceed to the church?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Are you agreed or no?

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Pray let me speak one word with him in private.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Yes what you please sweet lady, it is granted, were it a hundred pound to buy pins and petticoats.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: 'Tis not a thing sir, of that dear expense:
Though you were pleased to tax me for that crime ▪
'Tis only this, time was, I could not love you;
Though reason since, has rectified my judgement,
And cleared my eyes, that I can see my good.
Then I confess I made a solemn oath,
None should enjoy my love; but he that durst
Attempt to steal me; this is not intended,
For any peril to you, but for safeguard
Of my first vow, which I must needs perform.
Now if you please to come at a set hour,
None but yourself, and fetch me, I will yield
To go with you, whither you shall command.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: 'Tis done bright Helen, I will be thy Paris,
And fetch thee, though thou were't at Lacedaemon,
And care not a pin, for all the power of Greece.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: Yes, we are both agreed.
Some few ceremonies, and then we have finish.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Fido, I am now advised upon a plot,
If it succeed, shall crown my invention.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Something about the captain.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Hang him Kastrill.
I scorn to lose a thought on him; my brains
Repine at his memory. 'tis a new device,
The issue of extremity. 'tis thus,
I will turn a desperate gamester in love,
And venture all upon one cast.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Take heed sir,
There may be plots, but little policy,
Fortune and love, are insolent, and ticklish.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come I'll do it. I'll send thee with a letter
Unto my mistress, that shall make her mad.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: How, make her mad, what do you expect from that: what can you gain by the loss of her wits?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I shall gain my desire.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: And do you prize
The satisfying of a lewd desire
So much, to rob your mistress of her senses?
Can you accuse her of inconstancy?
Or tax her of dishonesty? Or will you
Prove false to her? what mischief do you intend?
What hopes can you conceive, that may secure
So great a sin from heaven's just punishment?
Have you a drug or incantation,
And think to make her senseless of her grief,
With the privation of her understanding?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not any of these.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: If you do, you must employ
Some other messenger. Let me advise you
Keep her in her right mind while you have her:
Love of itself is an illusive spirit,
And will enough distract her without help.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She shall seem mad but in appearance Fido;
And with that feigned frenzy move a pity
From all, that must impute it to her sufferings.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: 'Twere a mad jest: but is this all your plot?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No, this is not the main one, there's another
Of greater consequence, and secrecy,
For a sound mind to bear, and 'tis a burden
Worthy thy care and honesty: think not
I am so desperate and heady, to launch forth
Into those dangerous seas without a pilot,
And I have chose thee for my Palinurus.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: You never knew a man of less experience,
I do not ken one rock, or shelf, and love
Has many.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter, thou and I
Will sink a Paean to loves victory.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Careless, captain, lieutenant, Lackewit, four wenches.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: Come my voluptuaries, my sons of comfort,
That know no sorrow, sing like grasshoppers
And fear no winter, nor no poverty;
Lead on my moving pillars of delight,
My alchemists of pleasure, that convert
All like yourselves: can make old Cato dance,
And turn Fabricius to an epicure,
Should he behold you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Thou sayest right Telemachus;
'Tis wine, and mirth that breed these raptures in thee.
Body of Jove, there's nothing but a rabble
Of lean and starved imaginations
Accompany sobriety: some wine there,
That I may court my cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: Good captain
Bid our noble friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You know my humour,
To men of ordinary pretence, I seldom
Use to debase myself below the nod
Of salutation, but for your sake
I receive him as a man deserving.
Give me thy hand Cadmus.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I desire sir to incorporate myself into your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis well said, do the like noble office to our friend here sweet lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir he shall command my heart and hand on his occasions, I'll as soon draw in his quarrel, as to piss against a wall.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: These are the mirrors of the time old boy, that shall show you how to adorn your behaviour, that you may pass in all company with confidence of approbation.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And not err the breadth of a nail.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: He shall be able to pass through the needles of all occurrences.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: And they would but learn me to swear and take tobacco, 'tis all I desire.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Come they shall do it, and I must tell you, these suggestions in you are arguments of a generous disposition, whence do they flow I wonder?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That mother wit that put them in my head, has put money in my purse, and as far as that money will lead me, I will be bold and wise: I have my humours, and I scorn the pollution of the mechannicks.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: How do you like these replies captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Very well, by the faith of a soldier, excellent well, they are good relishing answers, and express an ebullition in his nature, swelling to conformity.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What, I will bear myself like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, and the way to bear yourself like a gentleman, is sometimes not to be able to bear yourself at all. Lieutenant, what say you?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I say by Hermes, he that has a fortune,
And power to acquaint the world with his perfections,
And seeks to smother them, let him die wretched.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You have no other way then this, to render you worthy of society.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What, he may turn stinkard, and live in the country with roots and bacon, and not drink a cup of good wine in a twelvemonth, nor know how the year goes about, but by observation of husbandry. He may keep two couple of dogs and a sparrow-hawk, and level his discourse by them. He may be styled a civil gentleman, ten spheres below a fool: he may marry a knight's daughter, a creature out of fashion, that has not one commendable quality, more than to make a corner pie and a salad, no manner of courtship, but two or three dances, as old as monsieur, and can play a few lessons on the virginals that she learned of her grandam: besides she is simple, and dull in her dalliance.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: He tells thee right my brave Frisker, they are lumpish girls, heavy in their sport, and cannot move with art.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
There's a wench, has her suburb tricks about her I
warrant you: hold there Bellerophon, take thy Ocyrois, and mount her like Phlegon.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Now do I want some two or three good oaths, to express my meaning withal.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Captain, what think you, shall he be a brother?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: Yes he deserves it, let him be a brother.
Give him the principles of the brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Are you resolved to be a brother sir?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Any thing I, you shall make a blowing horn, or what you list of me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nothing can be suddenly perfect, but must aspire by progression, he must be practised in certain duties, before he can be an engrafted member of the fraternity.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: He shall do any thing that is requisite.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well then, for the first two months we must dine every day at a tavern, where it shall be lawful for any brother to bring his shadow with him; and besides the full income of wine and provision, to bespeak any superfluous dish that he affects: but that which shall most commend the discretion of your worth, is, that after the dissolution of the feast, no man besides yourself must know what's to pay, or take notice of the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I must pay all, must I?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You understand me rightly, and I applaud your capacity; from thence, we must have a coach attend at the door, to carry us to a play, and at night to a bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: And all at my charges?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What else? And if any brother need a cloak, or a suit, or so, you must not stay till he publish or intimate his wants; but presently, by the strength of your own Minerva, pick out the meaning, and take order to supply him: have you any credit with the tradesmen?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Yes, I have a tailor that will trust me for any thing that I'll have him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That tailor shall have custom, tell him so; and one thing more, now brother, for so I must call you, we must have all things in common, no difference in the possession of any thing.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Pray explain that rule to me, I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why thus; this hat is mine, and that yours, as you conceive now, but they are neither mine nor yours upon the premises: but may be transferred upon occasion to either, as thus, do you conceive me? 'tis usual amongst us.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, is this all?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll make but one experiment more of your apprehension, and have done. Look you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O I shall do this to a hair, and by the same consequence I shall be a captain sometimes: shall I not?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, when the date of your task is accomplished, you shall be any thing.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, this once a week will render him exact. Shall's have a song and a dance captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hang a song, you see what little room we have for our mirth, and you would fill it up with air, would you?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Nay, but by that air, I hold a song very delightsome, the very place, as a man would say, and superficies of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Prithee let it alone, by that element it charms me into melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Then good captain let's have a dance, for these gentlewomen's sakes; besides there be many that come to see nothing else.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why can you dance?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What a question is there to a man of quality? Yes I can dance, and that some that are here shall see and feel before we part; for I mean to shake my heels with that fervour, that it shall strike them into a fit of my love, shall be worse than any ague to them.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Say you so? We'll try that i'faith. Come on squeakers, rack up our feet and ears to your instruments.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What tune captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Play us the fine companion.

div.p: Well said my effeminate varlets, this was auspiciously performed.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am afraid this dancing will breed spavins in my legs, this caper has put me in remembrance of a click in my back, I got at my last vaulting.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No thou art deceived my noble hyacinth, 'tis a mystery will exalt thee Hylas, 'twill make thee rise I say, and put gold in thy purse, thou shalt follow the court like a baboon, when a thousand proper fellows shall shirk for their ordinary; 'twill make thee conversant with ladies, and they shall give thee diamonds to pawn, and thou shalt ride up and down in thy foot-cloth my little dolphin some wine there Tony: I called for wine an hour ago, and could get none.
Fill out sirrah. What's here the epitome of a glass? By the womb of Bacchus, a score of them are too little for a draught.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O lord captain, nine such hornets are able to sting a man to death.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: By saint George he that dies so, dies valiantly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What my bold bravo, be not afraid, and thou wert dead 'twere nothing, I'll come but with a troop of wenches: and a noise of fiddlers, and play thee back like Orpheus. What's to pay drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Sir you have built a sconce since you came in of thirty pounds, and before you have any more, my master intends to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What money have you brother?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Who I? O lord brother captain, I have not the third part of it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No matter, I ne'er think upon such transitory reckonings: come, let's have a health, and my brother lackwit shall begin it. Reach three joint stools hither drawer.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What to do captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll show you, you shall ascend here, and be captain of this fort: I'll ensconce you; come entrench yourself, and play from your battery, and so every man round, there take your lintstock in your hand, and give fire, now every man as far off as he can from the command of his ordinance. Farewell brother.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Why gentlemen, I hope you will not use me so, am your brother, why gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There drawer, take him for a pawn, tell him when he has no money he must be served so, 'tis one of his chief articles.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: How now, what are you preaching o'er your cups? Now you are in your pontificalibus indeed.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Good Crotchet help me down, I shall break my neck else.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: How came you there?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I know not, an ill hour of the brotherhood, I'll after them with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: You must stay and pay the reckoning first, besides the musicians expect something.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Who I pay the reckoning? 'slight I came but now in.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: That's all one, you were all of a nest, they are flown away, and there's none left but yourself.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: 'Sdeath the captain is gone away with my hat, and my cloak too, I tell thee I'll pay no reckoning.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: 'Tis all one to me, if you can satisfy my master so.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What shall I do Crotchet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Give him what you have, and if he will take your word for the rest, I'll excuse your hat and cloak, and say you lost them in a skirmish; you must scratch your hands in half a dozen places with a pin.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I so I will, come sir, I'll go in and talk with your master.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Besides, I have another business I came to tell you of, that you and I must do together, you shall reap the whole credit on't yourself, if you can manage it handsomely, 'twill gain you that reputation with your father, that you shall never lose yourself while you live again.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What is't Crotchet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Go in and I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir perhaps I might
With better judgement, and more thanks conceal
So great a wickedness, but my true love to you
Could not withhold it, you have read some storeys,
And these are things not unheard of in nature,
No newness at all, the self same lust and pride,
As well rules her that treads upon the flint,
As her that rides upon the necks of slaves.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Stay let me pause awhile; she is a woman,
Whose age and form might tempt me to distrust her,
But yet her manners forbid me to believe it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Believe't? She is a close adulteress,
Of most strange exercise, a fricatrice
Insatiable: and has she none but you,
That she can find to bait with her allurements,
To cover her lewd projects? This moved me,
I'd not have meddled else.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O do not wrong her,
Good sir do not wrong her, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You have been still kept ignorant, for my part,
I never yet expected better from them
I count them but as ordinary chances,
Trivial, and drawn out from the lap of fortune.
Believe me sir, there is no day so holy,
That ceases to betray a woman's falsehood,
My medicine works, I shall be even with her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I sought at first to make her mad in jest,
But now I'll make her mad in earnest: yet
'Tis not good to be too credulous; a word sir.
I must have better proofs than your bare word,
To justify this accusation;
Her virtue must not stumble at a straw.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir 'tis not threats that can extort from me,
More than I list to speak: I see you troubled,
And therefore will not leave you in suspense;
Know that I made myself experiment.
For all let this confirm you: this she gave me
Upon the premises.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O I shall burst:
Here is a sight to make the sun run backward;
Good sir forgive me, that I pressed you so,
Consider't as your own case: were you he,
That put your confidence, your happiness,
All in a woman's love, and found her false?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I must confess I think it would afflict me:
I'll leave you sir, I have discharged my conscience.
But of more ill, than she has goodness in her.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: How now what planet struck? how do you sir?
This 'tis to be in love: what alterations
It breeds? it makes a man forget his friends.
Come sir be merry, your project has taken.
She fell into her fit, soon as she read it,
And tore the papers and talked idly, and showed
The symptoms of the prettiest lunacy.
What have you lost your speech? those folded arms,
And frowns, express a sorrow, more than love.
His eyes, though fixed upon their object, show
The wand'ring sphere of his disturbed mind,
Is whirled about in error. Pray look up sir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am not dumb, I have a care within me,
Speaks to my troubled soul.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O hear it then, and witness it for ever.
When ere thou seest a woman, in whose brow,
Are writ the characters of honesty,
And calls the gods to justify her truth,
Swear she's a Siren, and a crocodile.
Conclude her false, it is enough she vows,
And speaks thee fair, the winds wait on her lips,
Straight to disperse her oaths.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: You do but jest sure

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: There is not one of them, that is the same
She would appear to be; they all are painted.
They have a fucus for their face, another
For their behaviour, their words, and actions.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Come come, these are but qualms of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Give no faith to their brow: for in that green
And flourishing field of seeming virtue, lurks
A snake of lust, in whose voluminous wreaths,
Are folded up a thousand treacheries,
Plots, mischiefs, and dissimulations,
That man ne'er thought of. For in wickedness,
The wit of woman was ne'er yet found barren.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: I think he means to be mad himself too:
Your reprehensions are too general:
For by these words your own Valeria suffers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why there's the sum of all that I have spoke,
The abstract of all falsehood. 'tis a name, will
Blister the tongue of fame, in her report
Is drowned the memory of all wicked women.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Is your Valeria false?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Once my Valeria, but now mine no more,
(For they are perished that have lost their shame)
Is fallen from virtue passed recovery.
The golden organs of her innocence
Are broke, not to be soldered

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: In my conscience
You wrong her, this is nothing but th' abundance
Of love; will you go and sup with the captain?
And drive away melancholy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O no, my heart
Is shut against all mirth.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Then I'll go seek
Your brother out, and he shall go along with me:
I'll show him with a perspective i'faith,
What a brave captain he has: he shall be
In a disguise, as my companion,
Then if he will maintain a paradox,
That he is either valiant, or honest,
I'll be made the scorn of their company.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But my fate guides me to the contrary:
For if my mistress do not honest prove,
She has put a period to my life and love.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.l: Come, be not dismayed, whate'er you say,
I'll swear it: you must affirm you lost your hat
And cloak in a skirmish.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.l: So I will crotchet.
Mass thou wert not with us at the first neither.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Why what if I had sir?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.l: Thou mightst have carried
Away two or three of the captain's oaths with thee.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: I can coin them myself without any treason I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O crotchet, I am thinking now, how bravely I'll live, when my father is dead.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Yes, pray let me hear you.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: I have drawn the map of it already: I'll go every day in my cloak lined with plush, and my beaver hat, I'll keep my whores, and my running horses, and I'll maintain thee in as good a pied livery, as the best footman of them all goes in.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You will sir, what ungracious villain could have said this? where's your cloak and your hat? yes you shall have money to spend another time.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Look you, do you know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How comes this about?

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Nothing but the fortune of the wars forsooth: my young master has been in as stout a fray as ever the genius of Fleetstreet trembled at.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How was it son?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Let Crotchet relate. I scorn to be the trumpet of mine own valour, I.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Do, tell the story, Crotchet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Indeed he made them all run away, that I am certain of.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay but show us the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Why forsooth I came at the latter end of the feast, and the beginning of the fray, and there my young master was got above them all, and stood upon his guard, and held his weapon in his hand so dreadfully, as it he would have poured down his fury upon any man that should come near him.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: And will you be angry with him for this? 'twas well done, take no wrong of them, better lose all the clothes off from his back, than to keep a cloak for his cowardice.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Now is the time to move the other business.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well mother, if you will give me twenty pound more, I'll do you such a piece of service, that you shall thank me for it as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: What is it son?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Nay you shall not know, before it be done: the conclusion shall crown it.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Well husband, give it this once, and I'll urge you no more, let's see how the boy will employ it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes, send one arrow after another and loose both.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay, but give it him for my sake, I am confident he has a good project; you have example for it in your trade. How many have you, that break daily, and yet their friends set them up two or three times one after another?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Once more you shall prevail with me. Here hold, but if this miscarry, nor ask me for a penny again.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I warrant you, come Crotchet.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Must Crotchet go with you?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a business that can not be done by one alone ▪

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Well mistress, pray throw an old shoe after us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Gentleman you are very welcome. What hostess, come hither good hostess.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: You have a good handsome hostess, I perceive captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: She is cleanly and good condition '●●hats my comfort, and by the power of beauty, if a man were combustible, he might find in her eyes, that would kindle a conflagration.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What gentlemen be these captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Peace good hostess, I would not willingly proclaim their disgrace: one of them is a gentleman, that I bastinadoed the other day; and now he is come to give me a supper, to be reconciled to me, but take you no notice.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Captain here is a friend, that I would willingly commend to your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sir as I am a true soldier, I embrace your love in him, and that's as much as I can say. Hostess these are not ordinary guests with you; therefore you must be respectful: and faith if you say the world gentlemen, one of these nights, we'll every man procure as many of our acquaintance as we can, and be merry here at supper for crowns a piece. What think you?

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: This is not the business we come about sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know it well enough. Hostess, prithee good sweet, honey hostess, step and buy us a joint or two of good meat, and a capon, and lay it to the fire presently.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Where's the money?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Death to my honour, do not question it, but do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I have not sixpence in the world, the cobbler had all I had, for mending of your boots.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Go you must make shift, and get more then.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why if these gentlemen come to bestow a supper on you, let them give me money aforehand.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Speak lower woman, art mad?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I tell you I have not a penny in the house.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Speak lower I say. Go borrow it of thy neighbours, I'll see it paid.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes and turn me behind the door for my reckoning; you have served me so I know not how often, no I have trusted you too much already: you have not paid me a penny for your lodging, since you came to my house, besides what I have lent you out of my purse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Bane to my credit, you will exile me beyond the confines of reputation: go pawn some pewter, or one of thy brass pots. 'slight do not disgrace me, do any thing rather, take the sheets off from my bed.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes, you care not what becomes of any thing. Why can you not ask them for money?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Slife, a man may plot till his heart ache, and you still seek to cross me, you will undo me in my designs.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: You have more signs in your head, then hang at all the alehouses in town again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Prithee woman, hear me what I say. I know they come to spend upon me, and will crouch, and do any thing, yet when I out of my nobleness, and beyond expectation, shall use them so courteously, 'twill be such an engagement, that I can borrow ten or twenty pieces of them at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I tell you I can not do it, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith gentlemen I must entreat you to excuse me, my hostess is not very well she tells me, and I think she is not so well stored with necessaries to entertain you, as I could wish; and indeed she has ne'er a spit in the house, therefore we'll defer it till tomorrow night, when 'twill be more convenient at a tavern.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Well sir, your excuse shall prevail, we are not inexorable upon extremity.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: In his you have won me to your observance for ever.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p:
Captain I have another thing to propound to you, here is a friend of mine has lately received injury from one
master careless, and upon debatement of the matter, this gentleman is so apprehensive of his disgrace, that he can not possible put it up with safety of his reputation, and therefore desires to have it determined in plain field. Now as he is informed, his adversary accepts of it, and has chosen you for his patron in the quarrel.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By the shine of Phoebus, I wonder what strange impudence has possessed him. As I am a man to honour, I have brought him successively off from a hundred of these, to the peril of my life, and yet am daily obnoxious to new assaults for him.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Then you disclaim to have any hand in the action.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By the passion of valour, gentlemen I'll tell you, I love a noble employment with my life, but for such a pitiful, drunken, shallow coxcomb, I hate to be seen in such a business.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Do you think no better of him, captain? if he be so unworthy, I would advise you not to meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By the faith of a soldier, if he have any care of his credit, let him not deal with him, he will but defile himself with such an abject: I hold him to be so poor conditioned, I would not enter a country gentleman upon him.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Yet you keep him company, captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I confess I have done, and my intendments were good in it; I saw him so raw, and young, I was induced to believe there might be some hopes of him: but after much impulsion, when I found him so unapt, and indocile in his own nature, I gave him lost, and so I esteem of him, by my life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O thou treacherous villain, dost thou betray me to myself, and belie me to my face? how many quarrels have you brought me off from?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Never none by Jove.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will not rail at you, but I will cudgel you, and kick you, you man of valour.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hold as thou art a man of renown, thou wilt strike thy foot into me else, my body is as tender as a bog.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou cowardly perfidious rascal: have I for this made thee my associate, paid for thy swaggerings, and breaking of tapsters, and ostlers pates, fed thee at a charge a man might have built an hospital; drenched thee with sack, and tobacco, as thy face can witness?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O hold as thou art worshipful.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come sir surrender your robes, that you have polluted with cozenage. Here Fido, take this hat and cloak: I will not leave him a covering for his knavery: these are the trophies of your treachery, these.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay good sir do not pillage me of all, stay till I get my own again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If lackwit will restore them he may, else you must resolve to go bareheaded before your right worshipful fortune, with a truncheon in your hand like a verger, and so I leave you. Come Fido now for my mistress.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well, those good qualities that are bred in a man, will never out of him that's my comfort.

lg.l: And since I am the scorn of captains made,
I'll seek a better and more thriving trade.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come sir, now I have found you, not the power,
And strength of fate, shall pull you from my vengeance.
And though I know thy life too mean a ransom
For the redeeming of the priceless loss
Of her abused honour, yet what nature
Enables thee to pay, I'll take in part,
And leave the execution of the rest
Unto hell's justice.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What do you intend sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Look you: to unfold your heart sir with this sword,
And read the falsehood that is written in it.
Come I must know the truth, and reason too,
If there be reason for a wicked act.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: You mean about Valeria?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The same.
sp.l: Still an ill conscience will betray itself,
And sends forth many a scowling, fearful look,
To descry danger; if he stand confident,
And justify it to the face of terror,
Than she is false.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I hear she is run mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is, and the cause of her distemperature
Is the reproach you put upon her honour.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: The wound then is too deep, and an ill fate
Has driven the shaft of my intended malice
Beyond the scope I aimed at.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Was it malice?
That word has struck me both with joy and anger,
Both in suspense, which should weight down the scale
Of my deep burdened mind. What horrid baseness
Durst so attempt to profane innocence?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: It was my love to her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What is his hate,
Whose love has proved so ominous?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: That love
Being wronged, begotten that hate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thou hast done ill.
And like a foolish and young exorcist,
Hast conjured up a spirit of that fury,
Thy art cannot allay.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Repentance may.
I only meant to give her name a gash,
That might be healed again without a scar,
Or any spreading plaster of wide rumour,
With help of her compurgators, but only
To vex her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What's the offence that did provoke
This imputation? Did she ever wrong you?
Malign your wit? Disgrace you before your mistress?
Disparage your behaviour? Had she done so,
Yet this revenge were disproportionate.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Urge me no more, I cannot look on her
Without such a reflection of my crime,
As must give shame a lustre; there's no man
But once in's life may sin besides his nature,
Nay perhaps contrary: this is a deed
I must abhor to justify.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You have given
Almost a satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: 'Twas a scandal,
Arose from my repulse, and has no witness
Besides your ears; if it were silenced there,
The world were ignorant of it; I hear
She is run mad upon the grief, I am sorry
Her punishment has outstripped my desires.
I'll undertake, whate'er you shall propose,
For the recovery of her wits, or honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And I'll make use of your kind proffer sir.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I will resign her where she most affects,
And give you all assistance to obtain her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You speak honestly, I shall employ you;
I know you have that credit with her father,
You may advise him in a thing that reason
Shall seem to second; bring but this to pass,
You have made requital for all injuries.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Show me the way, I'll do't; be you the mover,
I'll be the instrument.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You are my genius,
My hope, my opportunity, my fate;
And in effecting this you cannot err,
To make me happy, and recover her.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Lackwit with a head-piece and a long sword, Crochet, careless disguised like Dotario.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: How do I look now Crotchet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Very dreadfully: like a citizen in a fray, as fear full as Priapus in a garden.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p:
Well, and thou art sure there is but one of them, and
he comes disguised like Dotario, to steal away my sister?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Yes sir, and this is the old gentleman himself, and somebody has stolen away his habit to abuse him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That man that has done so shall think of me and this place as long as he lives for it: go and give warning Crotchet, that no man withstand me, unless he be weary of his life.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: If any man be so hardy, let him take his chance.

sp.speaker: Lack ▪
sp.p: Let him expect my fury Crotchet. I will batter any man that shall come near me, my fist is like a sling, my head like a ram, and my whole body an engine, and I will make any man toothless that shall offend me.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Then you will make his mouth as unserviceable as your father's gummed velvet.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I long to exercise my puissance: thou art sure there is but one of them? stand by a little, and let me flourish with my sword, to animate my spirits; now whatsoever he is, that comes in my way, I pronounce him to be a miserable mortal.
What hast thou there Crotchet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: I imagined there would be a great deal of blood spilt in the skirmish, and so I brought these to wipe the wounds, nothing else sir: look you here they come.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Give by Crotchet, till I question them: it behooves a wise man to deal with words, before he descend to blows: what arrant knight are you sir? and whither do you travel with that damsel?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Press that point home.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O brother lackwit, how came you so accoutred? or were you set here for a watchman to guard us?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No sir, I do not guard, nor regard any man, and yet I'll stand upon my guard, and this is the point I'll maintain.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: What do you mean brother lackwit?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p:
How, I your brother? No, I scorn to have affiance with such a coney-catcher: you sir Nessus, deliver
up your theft, or I will play the Hercules with you.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I am going to marry her, my name is Dotario, and this is your sister Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Ay, she is my sister, but you are a counterfeit, and have stolen her away.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Seize her for felons goods, she belongs to the lord of the soil.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Thou villain, dost thou not know, if I were dead, and her other sister, she would be next heir, and than thou mightst be hanged for her?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: But I had her consent, and her fathers, my name is Dotario your neighbour, that have fed you with custard and apple-pie a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Ay, this gentleman has, but you have abused him, and took his wrong name upon you.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I am the same.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: He lies, beat him for lying, what do you stay for?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am considering with my eye, which part of him I shall first cut off.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Let's bind him fast, and then lay him upon his back, and geld him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: A match. Let's lay hold on him; what is he gone? how finely might my father have been cheated, and all we now, if I had not been: that's some roguing servingman disguised I'll lay my life on't; if I be not fit to be chronicled for this act of discretion, let the world judge of it. Well Crotchet, when I have married her to the right party, if my father does not give me forty pounds more, he shall marry the next daughter himself.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: You must not be too sudden now in the opening of your plot, after you have married them.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Advise me good Crotchet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Why before you reveal your proceedings, you shall present yourself with a great deal of confidence, and promise of desert; walk up and down, with a joyful agony, and a trembling joy, as if you had escaped from a breach, or redeemed your country: then when you see them sufficiently filled with expectation, you may draw the curtain of your valour, and stound them with admiration.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: So I will Crotchet, come let us to the church.

div.head: Scaena. Ii.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Come master Littlegood, be comforted,
I have as great a share in the misfortunes
Of your distracted daughter, as yourself.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: O do not say so, she was all my joy.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Then men begin to understand their good,
When they have lost it, and an envious eye
Seeks after virtue when it is extinct,
That hated it alive.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: You have reason
To pity me the more, and lament for her,
Because I destined her in marriage to you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: And I had well hoped to have been made happy
In her affection, a true lovers griefs
Transcend a parent's.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: No, you are deceived,
A parent is confined, and his joys bounded,
And only limited to such a subject,
And driven from thence, have nowhere else to rest on:
For if his children be once taken from him,
Which are the cause, than his delight and comfort,
That are the effects, needs must vanish with them:
But in a lover it falls otherwise,
Such as yourself, whose passion, like a dew,
Can dry up with the beams of every beauty
That shall shine warm upon you, need not prize
The loss of any; you have no alliance,
Nor natural tie commands you to love any,
More than your fancy guides you; and the winds
Have not so many turnings, nor the sands
So many shiftings, nor the moon changes.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Sir you speak truth, upon my knowledge that,
He is as slippery, as an eel, in love,
And wriggles in and out, sir, at his pleasure;
He can as easily dispense with vows,
As swear them; and can at a minute's warning,
If an occasion serve, supply himself
With a continual, and fresh entertainment
Of a new mistress.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Troth I must confess,
I have been a little faulty that way.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: And why would you sir, knowing this before,
Suffer your daughter to be abused by him?
Now by my life, I think, and 'twere not for me,
You'd wind yourself into such labyrinths,
You'd not know how to extricate yourself.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Peace good wife, since there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Do not despair, there is yet remedy;
I know a scholar, a great naturalist,
Whose wisdom does transcend all other artists,
A traveller besides, and though his body
Be distant from the heavens, yet his mind
Has pierced unto the utmost of the orbs,
Can tell how first the chaos was distinguished,
And how the spheres are turned, and all their secrets,
The motion and influence of the stars,
The mixture of the elements, and all
The causes of the winds, and what moves the earth,
And then he has subjected to his knowledge
The virtues, and the workings of all herbs,
And is an Aesculapius in physic,
No grief above his art.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Can he heal mad folks?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Were they as mad as Ajax Telamon,
That slew an ox in stead of Agamemnon,
He'll warrant them.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How should one speak with him?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I brought him with me, he is at the door.
Prithee go call him Fido, you shall hear him,
And as you like his speech, so credit him.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is this the man?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: This is the doctor sir.
I am bold to make relation of your skill here
To this old gentleman, who has a daughter
That is suspected to be mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Suspected, is she no otherwise?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She is stark mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It came by love?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes sure, what think you on't?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: An ordinary disease, and cure, in some things
I am of an opinion that Stertinius
The Stoic was, who held all the world mad.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: As how, good master doctor?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thus I prove it;
What is ambition, and covetousness,
Or luxury, or superstition,
But madness in men? and these reign generally.
Your lawyer trots, and writes, as he were mad,
His client is madder than he; your merchant that marries
A fair wife, and leaves her at home, is mad:
Your courtier is mad to take up silks and velvets
On ticket for his mistress; and your citizen
Is mad to trust him.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Nay he is a rare man,
And has done many and strange cures sir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Pray relate some of them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To satisfy your ladyship, I will.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Yes good sir, let us hear them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you. There was once an astrologer brought mad before me, the circulations of the heavens had turned his brains round, he had very strange fits, he would ever be staring, and gazing, and yet his eyes were so weak, they could not look up without a staff.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A Jacob's staff you mean?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Ay, and he would watch whole nights, there could not a star stir for him, he thought there was no hurt done, but they did it, and that made him look so narrowly to them.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you heal him sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Only with two or three sentences out of Picus
Mirandula, in confutation of the act; and as many out of Cornelius Agrippa, for the vanity of it.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: That was excellent.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The next was a soldier, and he was very furious; but I quieted him, by getting his arrearages paid, and a pension for his life.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: You took a hard task in hand, Mr. doctor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But the most dangerous of all was a Puritan chandler, and he ran mad with illuminations, he was very strangely possessed, and talked idly, as if he had had a noise of bells in his head; he thought a man in a surplice to be the ghost of heresy, and was out of love with his own members, because they were called organs.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O monstrous!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I and held very strange positions, for he counted fathers to be as unlawful in the church, as Plato did poets in his commonwealth, and thereupon grounded his conclusion for the lawfulness of whoredom; for he said that marriage, as it is now used, was the only ringleader of all mischief.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you heal him sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why lady with certain pills of sound doctrine, and they purged his ill humours.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That was very speedy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then there was a musician that run mad with crochets, the fit was so violent upon him, that he would nothing but sound perpetually.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you with him sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I served him as Hercules served his master Linus, broke his fiddle about his pate, and sent him away without ere a penny, and that brought his head in tune.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: I'll remember this i'faith.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then there was a huntsman that was very wood, he would nothing but hoop and hollow, and was wonderfully in love with an echo.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you reclaim him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why I served him in his own kind, he had a very handsome wench to his wife, and while he was playing the Cephalus abroad, and courting his Aura, I turned him into an Actaeon at home, set a fair pair of horns on his head, and made him a tame beast.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Husband that was excellent, was it not?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I cured a poet too, and indeed, they are a generation that are little better than mad at all times: I was fain to give him over, because himself, and others took such delight in his fury. I could not tell what to make of him, his disease was so pretty and conceited, and he was no sooner well, but he would presently fall into a relapse. I could make relation of a thousand such, as painters, alchemists and the like, but it would be tedious.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Nay sir, we are confirmed of your skill. Will you have my daughter brought forth to you sir, that you may see her in her fit?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No by no means, 'twill spend her spirits too much. I'll take her home with me, and anoint her brows with a little helleborum, and some other receipts that I'll give her, and I'll warrant you, I'll bring her safe too in three hours, and well recovered.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, you will do an office, that will not more deserve honour then reward.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, I shall desire nothing but my pains for my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good sweet Fido conduct him in, and go along with him, that if any hereafter shall be so averse, in his ignorance, to all goodness, as to question this miracle, you may be produced as a witness.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And what will you do sweet wife?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Why I'll stay here, and expect my son lackwit, with his project. He sent me word he would come presently, and see where he enters.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Crochet, bid them stay without, till I call for them. Make room there, and let such produce there game, that have good cards to show.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How now son lackwit; whither away so furious?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am sure all the wit and valour I had, was at stake for it.

sp.speaker: Lit
sp.p: Why what's the matter

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: There was old shuffling and cutting amongst them, and I had not spied their knavery they might have put a trick upon us, faith.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Why were you at cards son?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No, I was at dice. I came the caster with some of them I think, and I had like to have made their bones rattle for it. There was a rook would have gone at in and in with my sister, if I had not made a third man, he would have swept all away, and wiped our noses when he had done.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Tell us how was it son?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No matter how; but if I have not played the wise man now, and done an act worthy of applause, let me be hissed off for my labour.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Let's hear, what is it?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: If it be no more thanks worthy, I'll tell you at my leisure, when you have prepared your understanding.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What is it Crotchet?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Peace sirrah, I'll have no man tell it but myself, because the praise of it belongs wholly to me; and I could but effect half a dozen more such exploits, I'd write my own commentaries.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: You put us too much into a longing, son.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well I am content to open the sluices of your happiness; let them in Crotchet, but take heed you be not too greedy of it, lest the sudden joy overwhelm you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What's here, master Dotario, and my daughter Aemilia, hand in hand, and married together? Nay then 'tis as I would have it. The boy has done well, and I must applaud him for it.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O must you so sir? Well, there they are bark and tree, but as I am a hairy beast, if I had not been, they had been as far asunder, as temple bar and Algate.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How so son?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Why I'll show you. there was another changeling as like to him in shape, as Jupiter to Amphitrue, nay if I should say, as I am to, let me see what?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: To a fool.

sp.speaker: Lack
sp.p: No, to myself.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: 'Tis all one.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That would have married her in his stead, and carried her away, if I had not prevented them.

div.p: Whether it be a shadow or a ghost, that haunts him in his own proper form, I know not, but there he comes again.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why, how now son Dotario, you have made haste to beget one so like you already.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O sir, 'tis I am cheated, gulled, and abused, and which is worse, by one that says he is myself too.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why what are you?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O sir I am that old gentleman, that should have married your daughter, and there's an Asmodeus, a devil in my habit, that has beguiled me of her.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Come sir uncase, yourself; 'tis no glory for you to lurk any longer under the person of such a wretch.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Who is here, my nephew careless? nay then 'tis ten times worse than I thought of: my disgrace will be as common as conduit water, the very tankard-bearers will mock at me, I shall be made their laughter at taverns, the table talk at ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay good uncle do not think so ill of me, a brace of thousands shall chain up my tongue, that you may live as concealed as you please.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O sir you have proved yourself to be a fine companion.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Nay hold up your head sir, this was your device, your master piece of wit, and valour? nay you may brag of it, the credit belongs to you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Crotchet I would thou wert a post, that I might beat out my brains against thee.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Save you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Look you sir; here's the doctor, and your daughter already.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well there's some comfort yet to make amends for the rest.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Come down on your knees sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How now what are you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Lately the doctor, but now your son Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What more gulleries yet? they have cozened me of my daughters, I hope they will cheat me of my wife too: have you any more of these tricks to show, ha?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No more sir, if we may obtain your favour for these, and think good sir what love may do; you have been young yourself.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Troth and so I have, and been as waggish as the best of you. Well master Dotario, what shall we do? the boys have out stripped us, there's now no remedy, and my affection relents.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: So does mine too, and I would do any thing, if I might be freed of this ignominy, that it might not be known what a fool this love has made of me.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: I'll undertake for that sir if you will yield to a motion.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Any thing upon these terms.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Then thus: you are rich, and your nephew Aurelio here is poor, yet he was born to an inheritance; now do you but confer something presently upon him, and assure him the rest after your death, and I'll promise they shall observe you with as much obsequiousness, as you desire.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: And what shall my nephew careless do?

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Why master Littlegood shall give him his land again.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: If he will do one, I'll do the other.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: That he shall, I'll see that done upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I'll not stand against a good motion at any time.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Why then boys be happy in your mistresses.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir this speech from you is more comfortable than if Hymen had spoke it: and for my brother lackwit I'll take him to my protection, and stand in his defence against all machinous engines that shall be planted for the battery of his wit and fortune.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Pray sir will you get him his cloak and hat again that he lost in the skirmish.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I so I will; Fido shall restore them to him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well I would know, how all these things had come to so good perfection but for me now.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Nay, if fortune should not favour such as you and I are, she would leave her old wont.

div.stage: Enter captain like an host, lieutenant with a jug and glass, hostess.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's my old Reformado come again?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay you need not fear me now, I am as mild as my beer: I am her husband and your host till death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What turned host?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, and I thought it my duty to present you with the first fruits of my profession. Fill out a glass tapster, that I may drink to this good company. Gentlemen you are all welcome.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Is this your tapster captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, and does he not suit well with his function? he has learned already to run up stairs and down stairs, as nimble as a Squirill, and can answer to any man that shall call him, as loud and peremptorily as the best of them.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That's a good entrance.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: He is a little out of countenance at the first, but when you come to my house, you shall hear him speak in a big accent, what's to pay in the lion? what's to pay in the dragon? be not dismayed tapster, be not dismayed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well I perceive we must keep holiday: there's nothing angers me now, but master spruce is disappointed of his mistress.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Take no care for that, I have more mistresses than I can tell what to do with.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir I have a sister, though she had no part in this business, yet for her beauty, virtues, and dowry, may well deserve you: if you can like of her, I'll do what I can to obtain her for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir you shall command me in what you please, and my thanks for your love; and here I vow never to dissemble any more in this kind, but to be truly and sincerely affectionated to whosoever you shall commend me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay if you would not do so, you were unworthy of her.

lg.l: To gain a woman's love thus all may strive,
But wealth shall be put back, when wit shall thrive.
